titlePage.docDate: 1919THE STAGE PRODUCTION OF THIS PLAY IS BY STUART WALKER

castItem.roleDesc: a piano tester and socialist labor organizer

castItem.role: MRS. COMMISKEY , wife of a worker

div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: ANDREW GIBSON 'S office in his piano factory where he manufactures “ The Gibson Upright . ” A very plain interior ; pleasant to the eye , yet distinctly an office in a factory , and without luxuries ; altogether utilitarian .

Against the wall on our right is a roll-top desk , open , very neat , and in the centre of the writing pad a fresh rose stands in a glass of water . Near by is a long , plain table and upon it a very neat arrangement of correspondence and a couple of ledgers .

Against the walls are a dozen plain cane-seated chairs . Near the centre of the room is a sample of the Gibson upright piano in light wood . There is a large safe , showing the word “ Gibson , ” and there are filing cases . In the rear wall there is a door with the upper half of opaque glass , which shows “ Mr. Gibson ” in reverse ; and near this door is a water filter upon a stand . In the wall upon our left is a plain wooden door . The rear door opens into the factory ; the other into a hall that leads to the street .

Upon the walls are several posters , one showing “ The Gibson Upright ” — a happy family , including children and a grandparent , exclaiming with joy at sight of this instrument . Another shows a concert singer singing widely beside “ The Gibson Upright , ” with an accompanist seated . Another shows a semi-colossal millionaire , and a workingman of similar size in paper cap and apron , shaking hands across “ The Gibson Upright , ” and , printed : “ $ 188. 00 — The Price for the Millionaire , the Same for Plain John Smith —$ 188. 00 . ” This poster and the others all show the slogan : “ How Cheap , BUT How Good ! ”
Nothing is new in this room , but everything is clean and accurately in order . The arrangement is symmetrical .

As the curtain rises NORA GORODNA is seen at work on the sample “ Gibson Upright . ” The front is not removed ; but through the top of the piano she is adjusting something with a small wrench . NORA is a fine-looking young woman , not over twenty-six ; she wears a plain smock over a dark dress . As she is a piano tester in the factory she is dressed neither so roughly as a working woman nor perhaps so fashionably as a stenographer . She is serious and somewhat preoccupied . From somewhere come the sounds of several pianos being tuned . After a moment NORA goes thoughtfully to the desk and looks at the rose in the glass ; then lifts the glass as if to inhale the odour of the rose , but abruptly alters her decision and sets the glass down without doing so . She returns quickly and decisively to her work at the piano , as if she had made a determination .
A bell at the door on our left rings . NORA goes to the door and opens it .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Good morning , Mr. Mifflin . MIFFLINenteringGood morning , Miss Gorodna .

div.stage: MIFFLIN is a beaming man of forty , with gold-rimmed eyeglasses and a somewhat grizzled beard which has been , a week or so ago , a neatly trimmed Vandyke . He wears a “ cutaway suit , ” not much pressed , not new ; a derby hat , a standing collar , and a “ four-in-hand ” dark tie ; hard , round cuffs , not link cuffs . He carries a folded umbrella , not a fashionable one ; wears no gloves ; and has two or three old magazines and a newspaper under his arm .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: I believe I 'm here just to the hour , Miss Gorodna .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Mr. Gibson has been very nice about it . He told me he would give you the interview for your article . He 's in the factory — trying to settle some things he can n't settle . I 'll let him know you 're here .She goes out by the door into the factory . MIFFLIN , smiling with benevolent anticipation , places his umbrella and hat on a chair , then takes his fountain pen and a pencil from his pocket , smilingly decides to use the pencil , sharpens it without going to a wastebasket over by the desk ; then beamingly looks about the room . He is about to strike a chord on the piano , seems alarmed by the idea , moves away from it , dusts the lapel of his coat , adjusts his collar , studies the posters , shakes his head over them as if they were not to his taste , goes to the desk , and after studying it smiles at the rose and gives it a kittenish peck with his forefinger . NORA comes back and MIFFLIN turns to her with his benevolent smile .NORAgoing back to her work at the pianoHe 'll be right here .

div.stage: GIBSON appears in the open doorway , speaking with crisp determination to someone not seen .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: That 's my last word on it ; that 's in accordance with the agreement you signed two weeks ago .

sp.speaker: A HARSH VOICE
sp.p: We do n't care nothin ’ about no agreement !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: That 's all !

div.stage: He comes in . He is a man of thirty-something ; well but not clubbishly dressed ; an intelligent , thoughtful face ; a man of affairs . Just now he is exercising some self-control over irritations which have become habitual , but he is not uncordial , merely quiet , during his greeting of MIFFLIN .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: This is Mr. Mifflin , Mr. Gibson .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: How do you do , Mr. Mifflin . MIFFLINheartily , as they shake handsI am very glad to meet you , Mr. Gibson ! I hope you do n't mind my not writing to you myself for this interview .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Not at all ! MIFFLINtaking a chairI heard Miss Gorodna speak at a meeting two nights ago —

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: And learning that she was one of your employees I asked her to speak to you about it for me .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I see .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Now , in the first place , Mr. Gibson —

div.stage: There is a telephone on GIBSON 'S desk ; its bell rings .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Excuse me a moment !At the telephoneHello !... Yes — Gibson .... Oh , hello , McCombs !... Yes . I want you to buy it .... I want you to buy all of that grade wire you can lay your hands on . Get it now and go quick . All you can get ; I do n't care if it 's a three years ’ supply . There 'll be a shortage within a month .... No ; I do n't want any more of the celluloid mixture .... No , I do n't want it . They can n't make a figure good enough . I 've got my own formula for keys and we 're going to make our own mixture .... I 'm going to have my own plant for it right here . I can make it just under fifty per cent , better than I can buy it .... Wait a minute ! I want you to get hold of that lot of felt over in Newark ; the syndicate 's after it , but I want you to beat them to it . Do n't go to Johnson . You go to Hendricks — he 's Johnson 's brother-in-law . You tell him as my purchasing agent you 've come to finish the talk I had with him the other night . You 'll find that does it .... All right . Wait ! Call me up to-morrow afternoon ; I 'm on the track of a stock of that brass we 've been using . We may get three-eighths of a cent off on it . I 'll know by that time . All right !... All right !Then he hangs up the receiver and turns to MIFFLIN .Where do you propose to publish this interview , Mr. Mifflin ? MIFFLINcheerilyOh , I shall select one of the popular magazines in sympathy with my point of view in these matters . You probably know my articles . Numbers of them have been translated . One called “ Coöperation and Brotherhood ” has been printed in thirteen languages and dialects , including the Scandinavian . But I expect this to be my star article .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Because your factory here is so often called a model factory . “ The model factory ! ”He repeats the phrase with unction .GIBSONwearilyYes , model because it has the most labour trouble ! MIFFLINenthusiasticallyThat is the real reason why it will be my star article . As you may know from my other articles this problem is where I am in my element .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes ; I understood so from Miss Gorodna .

div.stage: Giving him an inimical glance , NORA closes the top of piano , and moves to go . GIBSON checks her with a slight gesture .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Would you mind staying , Miss Gorodna ? Miss Gorodna knows more about one side of this factory than I do , I 'm afraid , Mr. Mifflin . We may need her for reference , especially as she seems to be the ringleader of the insurgents . MIFFLINwith jovial reproachNow , now ! Before we come to that , Mr. Gibson , suppose we get at the origin of this interesting product .He waves to the sample piano .Let 's see ! I understand it was never your own creation , Mr. Gibson ; that you inherited this factory from your father .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Oh , no , I did n't . NORAchallengingWhat !She checks herself .I beg your pardon !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: The piano factory I inherited from my father was about one third this size . MIFFLINgenially ; always genialNevertheless , you inherited it . We know that everything grows with the times , naturally . Let us simply state that it was a capitalistic family inheritance . NORAunder her breath but emphaticallyYes !

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Up to the time of your inheriting it , you , I suppose , had led the usual life of pleasure of the wealthy young man ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 'd been through school and college and through every department of the factory . That was n't hard ; it was a pretty run-down factory , Mr. Mifflin .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: And then at your father 's death the lives and fortunes , souls and bodies of all these workmen passed into your hands ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Not quite that ; there were only forty-one workmen , and nineteen of them did n't stay when father died . They got other jobs before I could stop them .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: And how many men have you now ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I believe there are one hundred and seventy-five on the pay roll now .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: One hundred and seventy-fivewith gustolabourers !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Some of them are ; some of them are orators . MIFFLINjoviallyAh , I 'm afraid that 's hard on Miss Gorodna . GIBSONquietlyShe 's both .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: I understand you are not fighting the labour unions ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No . The workmen themselves declined to unionize the factory .

lg.l: : Mr. Gibson , when your father began manufacturing “ The Gibson

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: He did n't . He made a very fine piano — and only a few of them . It was “ The Gibson Upright ” that saved the factory . You see , with this model we began to get on a quantity-production basis . That 's why the business has grown and is growing .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: You mean that “ The Gibson Upright ” is the reason for the present great prosperity of this plant ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes .

lg.l: Now be careful , Mr. Gibson ; I 'm going to ask a trap question .
What is the reason for “ The Gibson

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Do you mean who designed it ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Oh , no , no , no ! I mean who makes them ? If someone asked you if you 're the man that makes “ The Gibson Upright ” would n't you say “ Yes ? ”

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Certainly ! MIFFLINtriumphantlyAh , there you fell into the trap !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What 's the matter ? NORAwith controlled agitationIt 's the same old matter , Mr. Gibson . It 's those men out there that make the piano . GIBSONa little sadlyDo they ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: With their hands , Mr. Gibson !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Is there anything more , Mr. Mifflin ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: You could n't possibly imagine how much you 've given me , Mr. Gibson , in these few little answers . It is precisely what I want to get at — the point of view ! The point of view is all that is separating the classes from the masses to-day . And I think I have yours already . Now I want to go to the masses if you will permit me .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Then you might as well stay here .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Ah , but I want to hear the workers talk !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , this is the best place for that ! Some of them are waiting now just outside the door . I 'll let you hear them .

div.stage: Goes to the factory door and opens it ; two workingmen come in . One is elderly , with gray moustache and beard — CARTER . The other , FRANKEL , is a Hebraic type , eager and nervous ; younger .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What do you and Frankel want , Carter ? CARTERmoving his jaw from side to side , affecting to chew to gain confidenceWell , Mr. Gibson , to come down to plain words — there ai n't no two best ways o ’ beatin ’ about the bush .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I know that .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: The question is just up to where there ai n't no two best ways out of it . The men in our department is going to walk out to the last one , and if there was any way o ’ stoppin ’ it by argument I 'd tell you . We 're goin ’ out at twelve o'clock noon to-day , the whole forty-eight of us .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: “ Why , ” Mr. Gibson ! Did you want to know why ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes , I do . You men signed an agreement with me just eleven days ago — FRANKELhotly protestingBut we never understood it when we signed it . How 'd we know what we was signing ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Ca n't you read , Frankel ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: What 's reading got to do with it , when it reads all one way ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Did n't you understand it , Carter ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well — I can n't say I did .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Why can n't you say it ? It was plain black and white .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , I was kind o ’ foggy about the overtime .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: The agreement was that you were to have time and a half for overtime . What was foggy about that ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , I do n't say you did n't give us what we was askin ’ right then ; but things have changed since then .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What 's changed in eleven days ? FRANKELhotlyWhat 's changed ? How about them men in the finishin ’ department that do piecework ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , what 's changed about them ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Well , something is goin ’ to change over there .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: We 're talking about your department not understanding the agreement . What 's the finishing department got to do with that ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Well , they 're kickin ’ , too , you bet !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 'm dealing with your kick now .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , o ’ course we got to stand with them ; if they do piecework overtime they do n't get no more for it .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 'll deal with them separately .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: My goodness , Mr. Gibson , you got to deal with us , too ! Not a one of us understood what our last agreement with you was . It 's just agreements and agreements and agreements — you might think we was living just on agreements ! By rights we ought to have double time instead of time and a half !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Time and a half eleven days ago ; now you strike for double time ! Where does this thing stop ? You want double time for overtime ; your working day has been reduced ; it wo n't be long till you want that cut down again .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Sure ! We want it cut down right now !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Yes , Mr. Gibson ; that was another point they told us to bring up before we walk out . GIBSONwith growing exasperationI suppose you want a six-hour day so you 'll have more overtime to double on me ! Then you 'll want a four-hour day , wo n't you ? MIFFLINbeaming and noddingWell , why not , Mr. Gibson ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Why should n't they ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Why should n't they ? But what 's their limit ? NORAoratoricallyWhen the workman shall own his tools !

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Of course that means all the tools , Mr. Gibson . You may not know our phrase : “ The workman shall own his tools . ” It means not only the carpenter 's bench , the plane and the saw , the adze and the auger , but the shop itself . It means that the workmen shall own the factory . It means the elimination of everything and everyone who stands between him and the purchaser , to take toll and unearned profit from the worker , who is really the sole producer of wealth .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: It means the elimination of capital and the capitalist !

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: It means that not only should the worker own tools and factory but should sit here in the persons of his chosen and elected fellow workers , as arbiter of his own destiny .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: That is to say , it means the elimination of me . MIFFLINjoviallyPrecisely ! Precisely ! GIBSONas another workingman strides into the roomWhat do you want , Shomberg ?

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Them new windows in the assembling room — they 're no good .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: We 've just spent twelve hundred dollars fixing them as you said you wanted them . What 's the matter with them ?

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: They do n't give no light .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: None at all ?

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: It 's right next to none at all ! The men are goin ’ to lay off if they got to work in that room . They 're goin ’ out anyway at twelve o'clock .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Now look here , Mr. Gibson , if I was running this factory —

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You 're not , Frankel !

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Well , why can n't you listen to him ? Do n't we even get no hearing ? I guess if I was running this factory once , the first thing I 'd do I 'd anyhow try to listen what the troubles is and make my men contented .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What would you do if you were running the factory , Carter ? You have n't said .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: I ai n't had the chance to say . Now what I 'd do , first I 'd settle all the grievances so there would n't be no more complaints .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , here 's one coming I might leave to you on that basis .

div.stage: Enter SIMPSON , an elderly worker in overalls and jumper ; and SALVATORE , a New Yorkized Italian type , a formerly lighted cigarette dangling from his lips .

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Our department 's goin ’ to walk out at twelve , noon , Mr. Gibson . We ai n't satisfied .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Well , we ai n't satisfied , Mr. Gibson ; we ai n't satisfied at all .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You got every demand answered yesterday , Salvatore .

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Oh , I ai n't talkin ’ about no demands . If all them other departments walks out we 're going to stand by ‘ em ! We got plenty to do with our time . Workin ’ all the time ai n't so enjoyable .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: So you people are going out again , are you ?

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: I guess it 's a general strike , Mr. Gibson . I 'm afraid if you do n't give the boys satisfactory answers the place will close down at noon .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Have satisfactory answers ever satisfied you ?

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Ai n't we got no right to stand up for our rights ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Do n't you get all you can from us ? Well , you bet your life we 're goin ’ to keep on gettin ’ all we can from you !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Then life is n't worth anything to either of us — if it 's all fight ! Is that to go on forever ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: No , Mr. Gibson ; it 's to go on until the abolition of the wage system !

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Good !

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: The struggle with capitalism will continue till the workers take possession of the machinery of production . It is theirs by right ; the wealth they produce is morally their own . The parasites who now consume that wealth must be destroyed .

div.stage: Great approval from workmen ; almost a cheer . MIFFLIN chuckles and noiselessly claps his hands .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 'm the parasite !

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Well , do we get any answer ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Does any one of you men here think he could answer all of these demands satisfactorily ?

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Sure !All acquiesce : “ Sure , sure ! ”

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: You can n't put us off any longer with just no little bunch of funny talk !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 'll have an answer for you in fifteen minutes .Turns to his desk .That 's all .

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Better have it before twelve o'clock . CARTERas they goDo what you kin , Mr. Gibson . All the departments is worked up pretty unusual . GIBSONwearily dropping back into his chairOh , no , Carter ; pretty usual ; that 's the trouble .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: A splendid manifestation of spirit , Mr. Gibson ! I 'll just take advantage of the —

div.stage: GIBSON waves his hand , assenting . MIFFLIN overtakes the group at door , puts his hands on the shoulders of two of the workers ; and goes out with them talking eagerly . NORA follows . GIBSON sighs heavily ; the telephone bell rings . He takes up the receiver .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Who is it ?... Wait a minute !He takes a pad and writes“ Central Associated Lumber Companies . ” ... Wait a minute .Looks at a slip in a pigeonhole of his desk .Oh , yes , you called me yesterday .... This is Mr . Ragsdale ?... No , no , Mr. Ragsdale , I do n't think I 'm going to do any business with you . You asked me forty-eight dollars a thousand on 200 , 000 feet .... No , your coming down half a dollar a thousand wo n't do it .... I say seventeen cents wo n't do it .... Hold the wire a minute .Looks for letter in pigeonhole , but finds it in his inside pockets . Then he holds it open , looking at it beside the telephone as he speaks .Hello !... No ; I was right ; there 's nothing doing , Mr. Ragsdale , I know where I can get that 200 , 000 feet at forty-five dollars .... I say I know where I can get that lumber at forty-five dollars .... No ; I can get it . There wo n't be any use for you to call up again .... Good-bye !

div.stage: He paces the floor again thoughtfully , then abruptly goes to the factory door ; opens it and calls .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Miss Gorodna !

div.stage: NORA appears in the doorway . She looks at him with disapproving inquiry ; then walks in and closes the door . He goes to his desk and touches the rose .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Why did n't you take it this morning ? That poor little rosebed in my yard at home ; it 's just begun to brighten up . I suppose it thought it was going to send you a June rose every day , as it did last June . You do n't want it ? NORAgently , but not abating her attitudeNo , thank you !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: dropping the rose upon his blotting pad , not into the glass againThis is the fourth that 's had to wither disappointed . NORAin a low voiceThen had n't you better let the others live ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 'd like to live a little myself , Nora . Life does n't seem much worth living for me as it is , and if your theories are making you detest me I think I 'm about through .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: It 's what you stand for that my theories make me detest — since you used the word .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , what is it that I stand for ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Class and class hatred .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Which class is the hatred coming from ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: From both !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Just in this room right now it seems to be all on one side . And lately it has seemed to me to be more and more not so much class as personal ; because really , Nora , I have n't yet been able to understand how a girl with your mind can believe that you and I belong to different classes .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: You do n't ! So long as capital exists you and I are in warring classes , Mr. Gibson .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What are they ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Capitalist and proletariat . You can n't get out of your class and I do n't want to get out of mine .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Nora , the law of the United States does n't recognize any classes — and I do n't know why you and I should . We both like Montaigne and Debussy . You 've even condescended to laugh with me at times about something funny in the shop . Of course not lately ; but you used to . In everything worth anything are n't we really in the same class ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: We are not . We never shall be — and we never were ! Even before we were born we were n't ! You came into this life with a silver spoon . I was born in a tenement room where five other people lived . My father was a man with a great brain . He never got out of the tenements in his life ; he was crushed and kept under ; yet he was a well-read man and a magnificent talker ; he could talk Marx and Tolstoi supremely . Yet he never even had time to learn English .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I wish you could have heard what my father talked for English ! Half the time I could n't understand him myself . He was Scotch .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Your father was n't crushed under the capitalistic system as mine was . My father was an intellectual .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Mine was a worker . They both landed at Castle Garden , did n't they ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: What of that ? Mine remained a thinker and a revolutionist ; yours became a capitalist .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No ; he got a job — in a piano factory .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Yes , and took advantage of the capitalistic system to own the factory .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Before he did own it he worked fourteen hours a day for twelve years . That 's why he owned it .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: How many hours a day do you work , Mr. Gibson ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I have worked twenty-four ; sometimes fourteen , sometimes two ; usually six .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: In other words , when you want to work .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 've learned to do things my father never learned to do , and it commands a higher return .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: You take a higher return !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You mean I do n't deserve it ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Can it be possible that you think you deserve as much as any of these workers ? You do n't so much as touch one of these pianos that bring you your return . I do ! I work on them with my hands . Do you think you deserve as much as I ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No ; I do n't go so far as that .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Do n't talk to me as a woman ! My work is pleasant enough now ; but what work did I have to do before I got this far ? I worked sixteen hours a day , and when I was only a child at that ! Twelve hours I was sewing , and four I studied . If my father had n't known music and taught me a little your capitalistic system would have me sewing twelve hours a day still !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes , Nora ; when we learn how to do something we get better pay for it .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: We do ? Do you really think that ? That we get paid for what we do ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes ; that 's what I think .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Then what do you get paid for ? For nothing in the world but owning this factory . You 're paid because you 're a capitalist !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Is that all ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Why , look at the state the factory 's in ! The discontent you saw in those men — that 's the fault of the capitalistic system ! There are n't twenty workmen in the place that are contented .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You 're right about that ; and they never will be .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Not until the system 's changed . What are you going to do about it ? GIBSONwith quiet desperationThey 've driven me as far as they can . If they walk out I 'll walk out . I can stand it if they can .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: You 'd close down ? Your only solution is to take the bread out of these men 's mouths ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: If they walk out I 'll walk out ! NORAtremblingYou coward !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: That 's fair ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: You 'll let us starve because you have n't the courage to come to the right solution ! Do n't you mind starving us ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You mean you 'd starve if I quit . NORAvehementlyNo ; but because you 'd close the factory .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Oh , the factory could run if I quit , could it ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: That 's the capitalist ! They think it 's capital that runs the factories !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: And I 'm the capital , am I ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: What in the world else ?Touches the piano .You think you produce this wealth because you 've got your money in it ? You pass out a pittance to those who do produce it , and when they ask for more than a pittance you take their tools away from them ! If they rebel you set the police on them . That 's capital — and that 's you , Mr. Gibson !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Nora , you told me not to speak to you as a woman .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: I mean it !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 'm going to disregard it . Could n't you get your theories out of your mind for a while and make a little room there for me ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: My theories ! I have n't any theories ! I 'm talking about the truth , and the truth is my whole life . I can n't find room for anything but the truth .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Could n't you ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Ah , that 's a man 's egoism ! With the whole world seething so that its wrongs should fill every mind — yes , and every heart — until they 're righted , you ask me —

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I think you need n't make it any clearer , Nora ; I understand . NORAturning away , agitatedI am glad you do .The factory door opens to the impetuous arrival of a workingman of extraordinary size and vehemence , RILEY , a truck driver .RILEYas he opens the doorSee here , Mr. Gibson , fer the love o ’ heaven , do n't the truck drivers fer this factory git no consideration ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I do n't know ! What do they want ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Look here , Mr. Gibson , man to man , every department in this factory is makin ’ demands and goin ’ to walk out if they do n't git ‘ em . Ai n't we got no chance fer no demands ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I said : What do you want ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Why , we got grievances been hangin ’ over I do n't know how long !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What are they ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Why , all them other departments is going to git raises . You do n't think fer a minute the truck drivers ai n't going to —

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: How much raise do you want ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Sir ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: How much raise do you want ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: I can n't jest say right this minute . We jest heard what was goin ’ on in the other departments , and we ai n't had no meetin ’ to settle just what raise we are goin ’ to git . Now , Mr. Gibson , if I was runnin ’ this factory —

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , what would you do ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: The first thing I 'd do , I 'd see that the truck drivers did n't have no more discontent than nobody else . What becomes of your freight if you can n't run no trucks ? You got to look out , Mr. Gibson ! It 's us got the upper hand .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Go call your meeting and find out what raise you 're going to strike for .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Yes , sir ; I 'll do it .He goes out quickly .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: amazed and rather gentleAre you going to give them what they want ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No ; I only wanted to get rid of him a minute to think — or try to . NORAin a low voice , offendedOh , excuse me !She is going out .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Stay here !He seems to approach a decision — one of desperation and anger . Then he speaks crisply , but more to himself than to NORA .All right — they get it !Looks up at NORA , gives her a frowning stare of some duration .Tell Riley to call off his meeting , please . I want all those spokesmen for the departments here . I 'll give them their answer now .

div.stage: NORA looks at him , puzzled , bites her lip , and goes out quickly into the factory . GIBSON 'S expression is determined ; so is his action . He goes to the wall , brings two chairs , one in each hand , places them at the large table . Repeats this until he has chairs placed at the table on both sides and at the head as if for a directors ’ meeting . The door opens and SALVATORE , MIFFLIN , CARTER , RILEY , SHOMBERG , FRANKEL , and SIMPSON enter . They come in , speaking together ; most of them talking somewhat ominously .

sp.speaker: CROWD
sp.p: Well , he better !... We ai n't workin ’ for our health .... My whole department 'll walk out !... You bet your life we 're goin ’ to !... He need n't kid himself about our not meaning business !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Well , Mr. Gibson , we 'd like to know what conclusion you come to .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 'm going to tell you . Simpson , please ask Miss Gorodna to step in .SIMPSON merely looks out of the door , and NORA comes in quickly .Carter , take that chair at the head of the table . Frankel , Salvatore , Shomberg , sit there , and there , and there ! Riley , sit there . Simpson , there ! Miss Gorodna , will you please sit here ?They take the seats he indicates , but they look puzzled , somewhat perturbed ; whisper and murmur to one another .Thank you ! There ! That looks like a directors ’ tables does n't it ?

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: What 's this all about ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I want to ask you people if any of you ever knew me to break my word to you ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Oh , no , Mr. Gibson , we know you never break your agreements !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I want to ask you people : Have n't you found my word as good as my bond ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Why , yes , Mr. Gibson .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Sure ! We know you 'll do what you say .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Do you all agree to that ?

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Soit'nly ! You 're a gentleman .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Sure , we agree to it !

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Oh , well , prob'ly so .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: All right ! I 'm going to do something you do n't expect , and I want you to know I mean it . But before I do it I want to tell you something . Probably you wo n't understand it , but for a long time I had a pride in this factory . Building up The Gibson Upright was really the pride of my life . To do that I knew I had to have a loyal staff of workmen , and for that reason if no other I have given you shorter hours and more pay than the men get in any other factory of this kind that I know of . I 've done everything that can be done to make the shops healthy and light and clean . I certainly have n't been unfriendly to you personally . Any man in the factory was free to come in that door to talk to me any time he wanted to . I 've done my best and we 've been called the model factory . I 've done my best but — it is n't enough . It never has been enough . And I 've been told it never will be enoughwith a glance at NORAuntil the wage system has been abolished — until capital has been abolished and the parasite destroyed ! I say I took a pride in the factory for years ! Now I am no longer able to . I can n't take a pride in a squabble , and that 's all this factory has come to be . And I 'll tell you frankly — you men feel you 'd like to get rid of me ; well , I want to get rid of you . And I intend to ! SHOMBERGfiercelyYou goin ’ to close this factory down ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No ; I 'm going to give it to you !

sp.speaker: SEVERAL WORKMEN
sp.p: What ! GIBSONemphaticallyI 'm going to give it to you ! I turn it over to you , here and now . This property is mine , but the use of it is yours . Do n't you understand ? You 've said yourselves my word is as good as my bond . Well , the factory is yours . I 'm going to get away from it . You take it and run it .

div.stage: He gets his hat and coat .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: What in thunder does he mean ?

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Say , what 's the game ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: There it is ! Take it and run it yourselves , for yourselves . It belongs to every workman in the factory on equal shares .Throws keys on table .There are the keys of the safe , and the combination 's in the top drawer of that desk . It 's all yours as it stands , down to the very correspondence on that table , without any let , hindrance , or interference from me . FRANKELhoarselySay ! He means it !

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: All the money ours ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: The money for every piano you make and sell is yours — every cent of it . MIFFLINrising transfiguredGentlemen , a glorious time has come ! This is an example to every employer of labour in our land . I thank that power which destined all men to be equal both in service and reward that I should have chanced to be present to see such a splendid band of forward-looking fellows — of brothers , of comrades — come into their own ! Let us hope that this great moment but marks the beginning of an epoch when every capitalist and manufacturer shall see the light as Mr. Gibson has just done . As spokesman for these — these men , Mr. Gibson , I would congratulate you for anticipating the inevitable and certain world future ! You have done well for yourself to perceive it . I am sure on that account you leave here with their respect . And to you I should think it might be some relief —

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Relief ? I should think it might ! And you can translate that into your nineteen languages and dialects — including the Scandinavian ! As for you men — you would n't work for me — now see if you can work for yourselves ! Good-bye , Miss Gorodna !NORA , who has been looking at him tensely , inclines her head slightly . He opens the door that leads to the street and goes out decisively . There are exclamations from everyone , loud but awed . “ Say , look here , look here , look here ! ”“ Give it to us ! ” “ Equal shares ! Did you hear what he said ? ” “ Gosh ! Is this the end of the world ? ” “ My wife wo n't believe it ! ” ]

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Gentlemen , this factory comes into the possession of every workman in it on equal terms ; each has a like share in the profits . At last the workman owns his tools . FRANKELsuddenly , as if light had just comeGibson 's crazy !

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: No , no ! He saw the writing on the wall ! NORAas if entranced , her eyes to heavenIs n't it wonderful — wonderful ! MIFFLINbeamingBut we must n't forget that it entails responsibilities .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: We must n't forget that .The telephone bell rings . They all turn their heads in silence and look at it , MIFFLIN watching them , benevolently chuckling . The bell rings again .CARTERblanklyThe telephone is ringin ’ .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Well , answer it , answer it !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Why , you — any of you . It 's yours — it 's your telephone .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: You answer it , Carter .

div.stage: CARTER goes to the telephone and picks it up in a somewhat gingerly way .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Hello !... Yes .... Yes , it 's The Gibson Upright .... No , he ai n't here .... What ? Wait a minute .Puts his hand over the mouthpiece .He wants to know who it is talking .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: My goodness ! Ca n't you tell him it 's you ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: He would n't know who that was .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Tell him it 's one of the owners of the company . CARTERlooks at MIFFLIN solemnly ; then in a hushed voiceIt 's one of the owners of the company .... Wait a minute ; let me get that . “ The Central Associated Lumber Companies ? ” I hear you . Wait a minute .Looks round .This here company says they want to lower their bid for a couple hundred thousand feet o ’ lumber to forty-seven dollars a thousand . They say that 's a dollar lower than they offered yesterday and a half a dollar lower than they offered this morning — says got to know now .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Says they come down to forty-seven , do they ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Yes ; says so !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Well , tell ‘ em that 's good ; we 'll take it .

sp.speaker: THE OTHERS
sp.p: Sure , that 's right !... That 's a good offer .... Sure , we 'll take it ! CARTERat the telephoneWe 'll take it .Pause .You 're welcome .Puts down the telephone amid general buzz from all the others . They rise somewhat dazedly , but relaxing , beginning to take in their surroundings in the new life . SHOMBERG and SIMPSON shake hands . FRANKEL goes over and examines the safe . SALVATORE picks up a basket of correspondence from the desk as if it were a strange bug . SHOMBERG opens a drawer in the table . There is a buzz of congratulative , formless talk . They spread over the stage , looking at everything .MIFFLINtransfigured , his right hand liftedGentlemen , this is the New Dawn !

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: The yard beside GIBSON 'S house . Upon our left is seen the porch or sun-room wing of a good “ colonial ” house of the present type . A hedge runs across at the back , about five feet high , with a gateway and rustic gate . Beyond is seen a residential suburban quarter , well wooded and with ample shrubberies . A gravelled path leads from the gate to the porch , or sun-room , where are broad steps . Upon the lawn are a white garden bench , a table , and a great green-and-white-striped sun umbrella , with several white garden chairs .
Autumn has come , and the foliage is beginning to turn ; but the scene is warm and sunlit .

After a moment a young housemaid brings out a tray with a chocolate pot , wafers , and one cup and saucer and a lace-edged napkin . She places the tray on the table , moves a chair to it , looks at the tray thoughtfully , turns , starts toward the house — when GIBSON comes out . He wears a travelling suit and is bareheaded .

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: The cook thought you might like a cup of chocolate after a long trip like that — just getting off the train and all , Mr. Gibson .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Thank you , Ella , I should .

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: I 'll bring your mail right out .

div.stage: She goes into the house and returns with a packet of letters .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Thanks , Ella !

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Everything is there that 's come since you sent the telegram not to forward any more .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: It 's pleasant to find the house and everything just as I left it .

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: My , Mr. Gibson , we pretty near thought you was n't never coming back . Those June roses in that bed round yonder lasted pretty near up into August this year , Mr. Gibson . For that matter it 's such mild weather even yet some say we wo n't have any fall till Thanksgiving .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes , it 's extraordinary .

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Shall I leave the tray ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No ; you can take it .She moves to do so .Wait a minute . Here 's a letter from John Riley , up at the factory . Do n't I remember his son Tom coming here to see you quite a good deal ?

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Yes , sir ; Tom 's one of the factory truckmen like his father . He still comes to see me quite a good deal , sir . There is n't anything about that in the letter , is there , sir ?She knows there is n't .GIBSONabsentlyNo , no !With faint irony .He only wants to know about where to get a stock of truck parts that had been ordered before I broke connections with the factory . He thinks four months is a long time for them to be on the way and does n't know where to write .

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: He 's a terrible active man , Mr. Riley . Always pushing .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: So Tom comes round more than ever , does he ? ELLAcoylyHe does , sir !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 'm not going to lose you , am I , Ella ?

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Well , sir , up to the time of that change in the factory we had n't expected we could get married for maybe two years yet , but the way things are now — not that I want to leave here , sir — but it does look like going right ahead with the wedding !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Tom feels that prosperous , does he ?

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: I guess he is prosperous , sir ! GIBSONgravely digesting thisWell , I suppose I 'm glad to hear it .

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Yes , sir ; everybody 's glad these days up at the factory , sir . I do n't mean about just Tom and me , they 're glad .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You mean they 're all in a glad condition ?

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Oh , are they , sir ! Even the Commiskeys got an automobile last month !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , I suppose that 's splendid .

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Did n't you know about it , sir ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No , not a word . I 've been pretty deep up in the Maine woods this summer . Have you been over to the factory at all yourself , Ella ?

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Yes , sir ; visitors can go round just as they like to . They 're glad to have you .

lg.l: : When you 've been over there , Ella — you know which one is Miss

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Oh , yes , sir ! She 's one of the best in managing , Miss Gorodna .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You — did you — have you happened to see her ?

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Yes , sir , once or twice .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Did she — ah — did she look overworked ?

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Oh , I should n't say so , sir .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: She looked well , then ?

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Yes , indeed , sir ! Everybody 's so happy up there ; I do n't suppose none of ‘ em could look happier than she is , sir !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: They are all happy , then ? ELLAlaughing joyfullyYou never see such times in your life , sir !A bell rings in the house .I 'll answer the bell .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 've finished this , Ella .

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: Yes , sir .She takes the tray and goes into the house . GIBSON opens another letter , reads it . ELLA returns .

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: It 's Mr. Mifflin , sir .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: All right .

div.stage: MIFFLIN , beaming and bubbling , more radiant than in Act 1 , but dressed as then except for a change of tie , comes from the house . He carries his umbrella and hat and the same old magazines and a newspaper .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Ah , Mr. Gibson , you could n't stay away any longer !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: How de do ! Sit down ! MIFFLINeffervescing , as they sitIt 's glorious ! I heard from your household you were expected back this Sunday . Now confess ! You could n't stay away ! You had to come and watch it !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , I 've not had to come and watch it for four months . I do n't expect to watch it much , now .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: You do n't mean to sit there and tell me you do n't know anything about it !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No ; I do n't know anything about it .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Mr. Gibson , you 're an extraordinary man !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No , I 'm not . What I did was extraordinary , but I was only an ordinary man pushed into a hole .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Oh , no ; surrendering the factory was merely normal . What 's remarkable is your staying away from watching the glorious work these former hireling workmen of your factory are doing , now they 've won their industrial freedom . Myself , I 've taken rooms near by : I started to do one article ; now I have a series . And oh , the glory of watching these comrades with their economic shackles off ! Have n't you heard anything of our success ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Only a word from my housemaid . MIFFLINdelightedly , pinning himAha ! There ! What did she say ? “ Only a word ” ; but what was IT ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: It indicated — prosperity .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Ah ! Immense prosperity , did n't it ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I suppose so . Success , at any rate .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Success ? It 's so magnificent that now it 's inevitable for every factory of every kind all over this country .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: All over the country ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Not only all over this country ! The world must do it . Ah , they 've done it in a country larger than this already ! And these comrades right here are showing our country what it means . I do n't begrudge you some credit for having begun it , Mr. Gibson . But you only anticipated what all owners everywhere are going to have to do before the workmen simply take the factories . They 're going to take them because they have the inherent right ; and they 're going to take them now , either by direct action or by the technical owners , like yourself , seeing the handwriting on the wall .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What do you mean by direct action ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Why , just taking them !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: By force ? MIFFLINdeprecatingly but affablyOh , we hope the theoretical owners wo n't reduce them to such extremes . There might be a few cases that law-abiding citizens would regret ; but that is n't the big thing . Our work here is so far perhaps on the small scale , but it shows — it shows — that everything must be on a coöperative basis !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Everything ? My house , too ? MIFFLINbeamingYour house , too . GIBSONamiablyHow about your gold eyeglasses ? MIFFLINlaughingThose will be given me by the state . But seriously , are n't you coming to pay us a visit at the factory ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Since you ask me — what 's the best time ? I suppose the whistle does n't blow as early as it used to . MIFFLINlaughing pityinglyWhistle ! Oh , my dear sir ! This only confirms me in my old idea that the technical owners did n't have practical minds . You do n't suppose we abolished you , and then did n't abolish the whistle ? That whistle hurt self-respect . Really I 'm sorry it 's Sunday and I can n't take you over there this minute to see the great changes . Talk about collectivism ! That factory is the most interesting place in the world to-day . When the men were working eight long hours a day under a master it was all repression , reserve ; their individualities were stifled . Now they expand !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You mean they talk a good deal ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: I never have been in a place where there was so much talk in my life . They talk all the time ; it shows they are thinking .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Is n't it noisy ? MIFFLINdelightedIt is ! Every man has his own ideas and he expresses them . It means a freshness and originality in the work that never got into it before . GIBSONworriedOriginality ? You do n't mean to say they 've changed any of the features of The Gibson Upright .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Oh , no ; it 's the same piano — and yet different ! I almost feel I could tell the difference by looking at one . There 's no change ; yet now it has character . And those men — those men , Mr. Gibson — it 's brought out their character so ! They 're thinking all the time .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: They 're working , too , of course ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Working ! You never saw men work under the old capitalistic régime , Mr. Gibson ! Do n't think that this work is the driven , dogged thing it was when they had to . This is work with dignity , with enthusiasm , with spontaneity ! GIBSONrising , very thoughtfulWell , I ought to hope that it is , of course !He walks to and fro a moment , then comes and rests his hands on the back of a chair , looking at MIFFLIN .Mr. Mifflin , I went into this with open eyes . I was angry at the time , but I had thought of it often . And when I went out I went out ! Now I 've kept away and I do n't intend to do any prying — as a matter of fact , I 'm only back here for two or three days — but I have some natural curiosity , especially about certain particulars .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Everything is as open as the sunlight — no capitalistic secret machinations . Ask anything you like !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , then , do you happen to know what are the profits for these four months ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Frankly , that 's a detail I do n't know . But I do know that everyone is delighted and that the profits have been large .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: And no friction among the men ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: No — I — no , none at all ; no friction ; nothing that could be called friction at all .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Then it 's a complete success ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Absolutely ! Why , just let me picture it to you , Mr. Gibson . Do n't you understand , these men are not hirelings now ; they 're comrades , a brotherhood ! You should see them as they come from the factory in the warm afternoon sunshine . They stop in groups and continue discussions of matters of interest that have come up during the day . You hear the most eager discussion , such spirited repartee ; and in the factory itself these groups gather at any time . When there may be some tiny bit of friction it is disposed of amicably , comrade to comrade . And some of the wives of the workmen have taken the greatest interest ! Imagine under the capitalistic régime a wife coming and sitting at her husband 's side and taking up little matters of importance with him , as a wife should , while he worked ! Oh , the wives have caught the idea , too ! They 're proprietresses just as much as their husbands are proprietors . And you can see how keenly they feel the responsibility and want to share in settling all questions that come up . Then they walk home with their husbands , talking it all over . Mr. Gibson , I tell you , sometimes it has moved me . More than once I have found my eyes moistening as I watched it .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: And do you happen to know — well , have n't the men felt the need for a certain kind of general management of the institution 's affairs ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Oh , that 's all met — all met by meetings of the governing board , the committee .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No ; I meant , has n't any need been felt for a man with a certain specialized knowledge ? Say , for instance , to deal with the purchasing of raw materials ? MIFFLINsomewhat vague and puzzledI think they did do this through an individual for a time . I think the head bookkeeper was given charge of such matters ; at least I think so . But probably they found that the creation of such an office was unnecessary . Purely clerical work . At least I have n't seen him about for several weeks .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Was he there on just one share of the profits ?

lg.l: : Why , of course ! That is the sine qua non .
lg.stage: Paces up and down and halts again .
lg.l: So you say everybody is happy ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Radiant !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Everybody ? MIFFLINbeamingCome and see !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Ah — Miss Gorodna seems to like it all , does she ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Does she ! GIBSONa little falselyNone of them are happier than she is , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Miss Gorodna is the radiant , joyous sunshine of the whole place ! GIBSONsomewhat ruefullyWell , that 's pleasant news .

div.stage: ELLA appears from the house .

sp.speaker: ELLA
sp.p: It 's that old Ed Carter from the factory , Mr. Gibson . He heard from Tom Riley you was expected back and he 's come to call on you .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Tell him to come right out .Sees CARTER beyond ELLA .Come out here , Carter ! Glad to see you !

div.stage: They shake hands . CARTER is unchanged as to head and whiskers , but wears a square-cut black frock coat , or “ Prince Albert , ” with trousers and waistcoat of the same material ; old brown shoes , a derby hat , a blue satin four-in-hand tie .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: How do you do , Mr. Gibson ! I just thought I 'd pay my respects , as Tom Riley passed the word round the factory you was coming back .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Sit down , sit down ! MIFFLINexuberantlyHow do you do , Carter , how do you do !They shake hands and MIFFLIN pats CARTER on the shoulder .Look at him , Mr. Gibson ! Look at him ! Do n't you see what the New Freedom has done for him ? It 's in his eye ! That pride of liberty ! It 's in his step , in every gesture he makes .CARTER strokes his whiskers .You 're old friends — equal now , equal at last . I wo n't disturb you !Picks up his hat , magazines , and umbrella .He can give you more than I can , Mr. Gibson . Good afternoon ! Good afternoon !

div.stage: He goes out through the gate .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Sit down , Carter . Sit down !They sit .Well , is everything fine ? CARTERheartilyYes , sir ! It is , Mr. Gibson ! Indeed it is !Glances with some little pride at his clothes .I could n't of expected no finer . Fact is , I never could of asked for anything like this , even if I 'd been a praying man .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , I 'm glad to hear it , Carter !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: I knowed you would be , Mr. Gibson . It 's all just wonderful the way things are working out !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Everything is working out just right , is it ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Oh , I do n't say everything ! They 's bound to be some little mites here and there . You know that yourself . GIBSONgrimlyYes , I do ! What are your little mites , Carter ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , what mostly gits my goat is this here Simpson 's wife , Mrs. Simpson .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What bothers you about Simpson 's wife ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , what I says , woman 's place is the home , and this here Mrs. Simpson — I — I never could stand no loud , gabby woman !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You 're not neighbours , are you ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: No ! She spends all her days at the factory ; you might think she was running the whole place ! What 's worse'n that , you know they elected me chairman o ’ the governing committee , and she 's all the time trying to ‘ lectioneer me out . What she wants is to git Simpson in for chairman ; that 'd be jest same 's her bein ’ chairman herself , the way she runs Simpson ! That 's the only thing that worries me . Everything else is just splendid , splendid !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I understand you do n't blow the whistle any more . What hours are you working now ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , first we thought we ought to work about six ; but we got on such a good basis a good many of them are talkin ’ how they think that 's too much . It 'd suit me either way . That ai n't the trouble over at that factory , Mr. Gibson .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What is the trouble over at that factory ? CARTERwith feelingMr. Gibson , it 's the inequality . Look at me now , and look at Simpson . Simpson and his wife have n't got a child , and I got seven , every one of ‘ em to support , and my married daughter lost her husband and got a shock , and I got her and her three little ones pretty much on my hands . And Simpson draws down every cent as much as what I do ; just exactly the same . And if the truth was told he do n't work as much as what I do . Then , look at them bachelors ; they ai n't got nobody to support ! Well , that 's got to be settled !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: How are you going to settle it ? CARTERcheerfullyOh , the committee meetin ’ settles everything by vote . I 'd of put a motion about these matters at some o ’ the meetings long ago except I 'm chairman and they worked a rule on me the chairman can n't put motions . But some of us got it fixed up to git it put over at the meeting to-morrow . That 's the big meeting to-morrow — the monthly one . Do n't misunderstand me , Mr. Gibson ; I ai n't makin ’ no complaint about these here details , because everything else is so splendid and prosperous it seems like this here New Dawn Mr. Mifflin called it in his article .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Nothing else worries you then , Carter ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Nothing else in the world , Mr. Gibson . Except there might be some of ‘ em do n't take their responsibilities the way I could wish . Fact is , there 's so much talkin ’ gits to goin ’ over there sometimes you can n't hear yourself work . Me ? I 'm an honest worker , if I work for you or work for myself . But I can n't claim they 're all that way . Some that used to loaf , you can n't claim they do n't loaf more than they did ; yes , sir !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: They get just the same as you do , though , do n't they ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Oh , yes ! That 's the sinee que none ; it 's the brotherhood between comrades . I do n't mean to complain , but they 's one thing that do n't look to me just fair . It took me four years to learn my trade and I 'm a skilled workman , and now some Hunnyacks that just sends strips along through a chute — and it 's all they do know how to do — they used to git two and a half a day to my six , but this way we both git just the same . I says something about it did n't seem right to me , and one them Hunnyacks called me a boor-jaw . Well , then I talked to Miss Gorodna about it .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What did Miss Gorodna say ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Miss Gorodna says : “ But you both get enough , do n't you ? ”

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , do n't you ? CARTERscratching his headYes , plenty ; and it sounds all right , them and me gittin ’ the same ; but I can n't just seem to work it out in my mind how it is right .Cheering up .Mr. Mifflin says himself , though , it 's just wonderful ! And we certainly are makin ’ great money !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Then all you poor are getting rich ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Yes ; looks like we will be .During these speeches NORA has appeared , or rather her head and shoulders have , above the hedge . She has come along the hedge and now stands halting at the gate . She wears a becoming autumn dress and hat , in excellent taste ; carries a slim umbrella . She has a beautifully bound book in her hand .NORAopening the gateDo you mind my coming in the side gate , Mr. Gibson ?

div.stage: GIBSON , startled by her voice , turns abruptly from CARTER to stare at her , speaks after a pause , slowly .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No , I do n't mind what gate you come in . NORAcoming down to join themHow do you do !Gives him her hand .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: How do you do ! CARTERon the other side of herHow do you do , Miss Gorodna ! NORAfor a brief moment confused that she has not noticed CarterOh — oh , how do you do , Mr. Carter !Turns and shakes hands with him . She turns again , facing GIBSON .I just heard you were here . I wanted to bring you this copy of Montaigne — if you 'll forgive me for keeping it a year .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I gave it to you . Do n't you — remember ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Yes , I — remember . But things were different then . Please . I think I ought n't to keep it now .He takes it , places it gently upon the table ; they sit facing each other ; she speaks more cheerfully and briskly .I came to see you on a matter of business , too .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , then , I 'll just be —

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Oh , no ! Please stay , Mr. Carter ! It 's a factory matter .CARTER coughs and sits . NORA continues , not pausing for that .It was about that great stock of wire you had your purchasing agent buy just before the — before you went away , Mr. Gibson .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 'm glad to see you looking so well , Miss Gorodna .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Thank you ! If you remember , you must have ordered him to buy all the wire of our grade that was in the market at that time . At any rate , we found ourselves in possession of an enormous stock that would have lasted us about three years .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes . That 's what I wanted .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: As it happened it turned out to be a very good investment , Mr. Gibson , because in less than a month it had gained about nine per cent . in value , and three weeks ago a man came to us and offered to take it off our hands at a price giving us a twenty-two per cent . profit !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes ; I should think he would .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: So of course we sold it . GIBSONchecks an exclamation , merely sayingDid you ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Naturally we did ! Twenty-two per cent . profit in that short time ! Now it just happens that we 've got to buy some more ourselves , and we can n't get hold of any , even at the price that we sold it , because it seems to have kept going up . I thought perhaps you might know where to get some at the price you bought the other , and you might n't mind telling us .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No ; I would n't mind telling you . I 'd like to tell you .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: You think there is n't any ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 'm sure there is n't any .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Then I 'm afraid we 'll have to get some back from the people we sold to . Of course I 'm anxious to show the great financial improvement as well as other improvements . That 's partly my province and Mr. Carter 's , our committee chairman , besides our regular work .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Mr. Mifflin tells me that you had a sort of general manager for a while at first .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Oh , that was Hill , the head bookkeeper . He left . He was a traitor to the comrades .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Hill ? He knew quite a little about the business . Why did he leave ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Why , that Coles-Hibbard factory went and offered him a big salary to come over there ; more than he thought he could get coöperatin ’ with us .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Hill was always a capitalist at heart . We certainly have n't needed him !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Oh , everybody was glad to get rid of Hill ! Better off without him — better off without him !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I suppose it was really an economy , his going ? NORAsmilingIt resulted in economy .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Have you made many economies ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Oh , a great many !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Oh , my ! Yes !

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Economies !Her manner now is indulgent , amused , friendly , almost pitying .Mr. Gibson , have you any realization of what you threw away at that place ? Do n't be afraid , I 'll never bring you the figures . I would n't do such a thing to anybody !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Do you think I was too lavish ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: We could n't believe it at first . Just what was being thrown away on advertising , for instance . The bill you paid for the last month you were there was five thousand dollars !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: That was the figger ! It 's certainly a good one on you , Mr. Gibson .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: We cut that five thousand dollars down to three hundred ! That was one item of forty-seven hundred dollars a month saved . Just one item ! CARTERhilariouslyQuite some item ! NORAseriously and gentlyFive thousand dollars a month to advertise a piano that sells for only a hundred and eighty-eight dollars !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: That 's the facts !

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Mr. Gibson , did you really ever have any idea what you were paying in commissions to agents ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes , I did .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Why , I can n't believe it ! Did you know that you paid them twenty per cent . on each piano ? Over thirty-seven dollars !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: But was n't it thrown away ? I can n't understand how you kept the factory going so long as you did , with such losses . Why , do n't you know it amounts to hundreds of thousands of dollars a year ? When we found it out we could n't see how you made both ends meet , and we thought there must have been some mistake , and you 'd never realized what advantage these agents were taking of you .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes , I knew what they got . NORAtriumphantlyWe cut those commissions from thirty-seven dollars — to twelve ! And that 's just one more item among our economies . Now do you wonder at the success we 're making ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: And your profits have been — satisfactory ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: The very first month our profits were four thousand dollars more than the last month you were there !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: That 's the month you say you cut out four thousand seven hundred dollars ’ worth of advertising .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: And the next month we cut down the commissions , and the profits were five thousand more !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: But those were returns under the old commissions .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: But last month , with new economies , we showed a larger profit than you had !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: And this month ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: We sha n't know that until the report 's read at the meeting to-morrow . I think it will be the largest profit of all .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: That bookkeeper 's workin ’ on it to-day . Talked like he was going to cut us down two or three thousand , mebbe .Laughing .That 's the way he always talks .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: He is n't a good influence .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: No — too gloomy , too gloomy to suit me !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What about the two other bookkeepers ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: The committee voted them into the packing department ; and they ai n't much good even there . It 's a crime !

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: They were n't needed . Our bookkeeping is so simplified since you left !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: It all seems to be simplified , Miss Gorodna .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Yes ; and whatever problems come up , they 're all settled at our meetings .

div.stage: A sound of squabbling is heard upon the street , growing louder as the people engaging in it approach along the sidewalk .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: There 's one we got to bring up and do something about at the meetin ’ to-morrow .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What is it ?CARTER goes up to the gate .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: It 's that Mrs. Simpson ; she 's a great nuisance .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Yes , it 's her and Simpson and Frankel . The Simpsons moved into a flat right up in this neighbourhood . Quite some of the comrades live up round here now .FRANKEL and MRS. SIMPSON are heard disputing as they approach : “ Well , what you goin ’ to do about it ! ” “ I 'll show you what we 're goin ’ to do about it ! ” “ You can n't do nothing ! ” “ You wait till to-morrow and see . ” “ I got my rights , ai n't I ? ” and so on .SIMPSONheard remonstratingNow , Mamie , Mamie ! Frankel , you ought n't to talk to Mamie that way .

div.stage: GIBSON , interested and amused , goes part way up to the hedge . NORA is somewhat mortified as the disputants reach the gate . GIBSON speaks to them .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: How do you do , Simpson ! How do you do , Mrs. Simpson ! How do you do , Frankel ! Wo n't you come in and argue here ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: Wha 'd you say , Mr. Gibson ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I said come in ; come in ! SIMPSONuncertainlyWell , I do n't know .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Come in ! Nobody here but friends of yours . Sit down . I 'd like to hear what the argument was about .MRS. SIMPSON is a large woman , domineering and noisy , dressed somewhat expensively . She is proud of some new furs and a pair of quite fancy shoes . SIMPSON has a new suit of clothes and a gold-headed cane .FRANKEL wears a cheap cutaway suit and is smoking a cigar . ]

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: I do n't care who hears the argument ! Right 's right and wrong 's wrong !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: You bet right 's right , and so 's my rights right !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: You ai n't got any rights . FRANKELhotly to everybodyDo you hear she says I ai n't got no rights at all ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: You ai n't got the rights you claim you got .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: She comes down there and tries to run the whole factory . Ask any of ‘ em if she do n't . Ask Carter !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: I own that factory just as much as anybody does .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Now , Frankel , you be careful what you say to Mamie !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: I got shares in that factory and by rights ought to have as many votes at the meetin ’ as I got shares — let alone your talking about trying to root me out of my profits !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What 's this about Frankel having shares ? FRANKELviolentlyYou bet your life I got shares ! And I 'm going to have my shares of the money at that meetin ’ to-morrow !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: You bet your life you ai n't !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: You think we 're goin ’ to vote all our profits away to you ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Wait a minute ! Ai n't I the chairman of that —

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: You may be chairman yet — but not long ! FRANKELsharply to CARTERYou just try to rule me out once !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What 's it all about ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: I 'll soon enough tell anybody what it 's about !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: You could n't tell nothing straight ! CARTERdeprecatinglyNow , now , this here 's just one of our little side difficulties , you might say . What 's the use to git huffy over it , we 're gittin ’ along so well and all ? The trouble is , some o ’ the men and their families ai n't been used to so much prosperity and money in the house that way , all of a sudden . Of course some of ‘ em got to living too high and run into some debt and everything .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Well , what business is that of yours ? The factory ai n't a Home , is it ? And you ai n't the Matron , are you ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: I do n't claim such !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: It 's my business , ai n't it , if I take and live on the cheaps and put by for a rainy day , and happen to have money when other people need it from me ?

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: That much may be your business , but I reckon it was our business when you come blowin ’ round the factory , first that you owned seven shares besides your own ; then , a week after , you says seventeen ; then —

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , how many shares has he got ?

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: He was claimin ’ twenty-four yesterday .

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: violentlyHe 's bought two more since last night . Now he claims twenty-six !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Yes ; and I own twenty-six !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: That ai n't never goin ’ to do ! I do n't say it 's a condition as you might say we exactly see how to handle right now , but the way it is , you certainly got us all disturbed up and hard to git at the rights of it . You claimin ’ all them shares —

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Well , my goodness , you git the work fer them shares , do n't you ? What you yelpin ’ about ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: I do n't say we do n't git the same amount o ’ work , but —

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Well , how you git it , that 's my lookout , ai n't it , so it 's done ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: But you claim you got a right to draw out twenty-six profits !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Sure I do when I furnish the labour for twenty-six . Am I crazy ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: But that way you 're makin ’ more than any ten men put together in the whole factory !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Ai n't it just ? What you goin ’ to do about it ?

div.stage: During this speech SHOMBERG has come along the street and stands looking over the gate .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , so fur , we ai n't been able to see how to argue with you . It do n't look right , and yet it 's hard to find jest what to say to you .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: You bet it is !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: ‘ Course , that 's one of the points that 's got to be settled at the meeting to-morrow .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: You bet it 'll be settled !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: If we had another kind of a chairman it 'd been settled long ago , and settled right !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Now look here , Mrs. Simpson — FRANKELpassionatelyI got twenty-six shares , and I earned ‘ em , too !To GIBSON .Look at the trouble they make me — to git my legal rights , let alone the rest the trouble I got !Fiercely to CARTER and to SIMPSONYes , I had twenty-four shares yesterday and I got twenty-six to-day ! and I might have another by to-night . Do n't think I 'm the only one that 's got sense enough not to go smearin ’ his money all round on cheap limousines and Queen Anne dinin ’ - room sets at eighty-nine dollars per !Dramatically pointing at SHOMBERGThere 's a man worth four shares right now ! He had three and he bought Mitchell 's out last night at Steinwitz 's pool room . Ask him whether he thinks I got a right to my twenty-six profits or not !

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: You bet your life !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: I guess that Dutchman has n't got the say-so , has he ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: No . You run the factory now , Mrs. Simpson !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Now look here ; this ai n't very much like comrades , is it , all this arguin ’ ? Sunday , too !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Oh , I 'm tryin ’ to be friendly ! CARTERto GIBSONThis buyin ’ of shares and all has kind of introduced a sort of an undesirable element into the factory , you might say . That 's kind of the bothersome side of it , and it can n't be denied we would have quite a good deal of bothersomeness if it was n't for our meeting . NORAto everybody except GIBSONDo n't you all think that these arguments are pretty foolish when you know that nothing can be settled except at the governing committee 's meeting ?

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: That 's so , Miss Gorodna . What 's more , it do n't look like as good comrades as it ought to . I do n't want to have no trouble with Frankel . He might have the rights of it for all I know . Anyways , if he has n't I ai n't got the brains to make out the case against him , and anyways , as you say , the meetin ’ settles all them things .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Do n't you think you and Frankel might shake hands now , like good comrades ? FRANKELwith hostilitySure , I 'll shake hands with him !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Well , I just as soon .

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: Do n't you do it , Henry !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Well , but he 's a comrade .

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: Well , you can n't help that ! You do n't have to shake hands with him .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Well , consider it done , Frankel . Consider it done !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: That 's right , that 's right ! We can leave it to the meeting .

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: You bet you can ! You goin ’ my way , Frankel ?

div.stage: FRANKEL , joining him , speaks to MRS. SIMPSON .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: I s'pose you 're going to come to the meetin ’ , Mrs. Simpson ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: Ai n't my place where my husband is ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Well , you do n't git no vote !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: There 's goin ’ to be a motion introduced for the wives to vote .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Watch it pass ! Good-bye , Mr. Gibson !

div.stage: GIBSON nods . FRANKEL goes away with SHOMBERG .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Good-bye , Mr. Gibson ! All this do n't amount to much . It 'll all be settled to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: Good-bye , Mr. Gibson !And as they go out the gateYou bet your life it 'll be settled !
