If that wall-eyed runt thinks he can walk over me — CARTERlooking after them , laughingWell , she 's an awful interfering woman ! And she ai n't the only one . If they 'd all stay home like my wife things would be smoother , I guess . Still , they 're smooth enough .GoingIf you want to see that , Mr. Gibson , we 'll be glad to have you look in at the meeting . You 're always welcome at the factory and it 'd be a treat to you to see how things work out . It 's at eleven o'clock if you 'd like to come .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Thanks , Carter .

lg.l: : Well , good afternoon , Mr. Gibson and Miss Gorodna . Good evening ,

lg.stage: The light has grown to be of sunset . CARTER goes .
lg.l: : I 'm glad to see you looking so well .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Oh , just a minute more .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: It looks as if that might be a lively meeting to-morrow .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Is that the old capitalistic sneer ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Indeed it 's not ! It only seemed to me from what we 've just heard here — NORAbitterlyOh , I suppose all business men 's meetings and arguments , when their interests happen to clash , are angelically sweet and amiable ! Because you see that my comrades are human and have their human differences —

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Nora , do n't be angry .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: I 'll try not . Of course it is n't all a bed of roses ! Of course things do n't run like oiled machinery !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: But they do run ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: It 's magnificent !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Do you want me to come to that meeting to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Yes ; I 'd like you to see how reasonable people settle their differences when they have an absolutely equal and common interest . GIBSONin a low voiceAre n't you ever tired ?

div.stage: For a moment she has looked weary . She instantly braces up and answers with spirit .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Tired of living out my ideals ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: No ; I just mean tired of working . Would n't you rather stop and come here and live in this quiet house ? NORAincredulouslyI ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Could n't there even be a chance of it , Nora ? That you 'd marry me ? NORAamazed and indignantA chance that I would —

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , then , would n't you even be willing to leave it to the meeting to-morrow ?

div.stage: Already in motion she gives him a look of terror and intense negation .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Oh !She runs from the gateway .

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: The scene is the same as the first , the factory office — with a difference . It is now littered and disorderly . Files have been taken from the cases and left heaped upon the large table and upon chairs . Piles of mail are on the desk and upon the table . The safe is open , showing papers in disorder and hanging from the compartments . Hanging upon the walls , variously , are suits of old overalls and men 's coats and , hats . The chairs stand irregularly about the large table ; a couple of old soft hats are on the water filter . The former posters have been replaced by two new ones . One shows a brawny workman with whiskers , paper cap , and large sledge hammer leaning upon an upright piano . Rubrics : “ The Freedom and Fraternity Coöperative Upright . ” “ The Piano You Ought to Support . ” The other poster shows a workman with a banner upon which is printed : “ No Capital ! The Freedom and Fraternity Coöperative Upright The Only Piano Produced by Toilers Not Ground by Capital . Buy One to Help the Cause ! ”
NORA is busily engaged at GIBSON 'S desk . Her hat and jacket hang on the wall .

CARTER enters , smoking a pipe ; he wears overalls and jumper . He carries a heavy roll of typewritten sheets . Tosses this upon the table , glances at NORA , who does not notice him , divests himself of overalls and jumper , and puts on the black frock coat which he wore in Act II . He looks at his watch and at the clock on the wall .

CARTER [ straightening out his coat ]: I thought it might look better to get on my Sunday clothes for the meeting , as you might say , Miss Gorodna . Being as I 'm chairman it might look more dignified ; kind o ’ help give a kind of authority , maybe .
NORA [ absently , not looking up ]: Yes .

CARTER [ looking at his watch and at the clock again ]: It ought to be wound up for meetings . [ He steps upon a chair ; moves the hands of clock . ] There , doggone it , the key 's lost ! I believe Mrs. Simpson took that key for their own clock . [ He goes to the table ; sits , unrolls the typewritten sheets , puts on his spectacles , and studies the sheets in a kind of misery , roughing his hair badly and making sounds of moaning . ] Miss Gorodna , can you make this figure out here for me ? Does that mean profits — or what ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Oh , no ; that 's only an amount carried over .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: They 's so many little puzzlin ’ things in this bookkeeper 's report . I do n't believe he understands it himself . I do n't see how he expects me to read that to the meeting . Some parts I can n't make head or tail of . Others it looks like he 's got the words jest changed round .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Oh , we 'll work it all out at the meeting , Mr. Carter !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: My , we got a lot to work out at this meeting .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: We 'll do it , comrade ! CARTERcheering upSure ! Sure we will ! It 's wonderful what a meeting does ; I 'm always forgettin ’ all we got to do is vote and then the trouble 's over .Instantly upon this a loud squabbling and women 's voices are heard outside , in the factory .NORAtroubledI was afraid this would happen . Of course after Mrs. Simpson came other wives were bound to . CARTERuneasily moving toward the door to the streetWell , I guess I better —

div.stage: The door into the factory is flung open by MRS. SIMPSON , in a state of fury . Another woman 's voice is heard for a moment , shouting : “ Old Cat ! Old She-Cat ! Wants to be a Tom-Cat ! ”

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: See here , Carter , if you still pretend to be chairman you come out here and keep order !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Now , Mrs. Simpson , you better go on home !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: ragingMe ! My place is right here , but I 'm not going to stand this Commiskey woman 's insults ! She come down here this morning with her husband and started right in to run this factory . My heavens ! Ai n't she got five children at home ? As long as you still pretend to be chairman I demand you come out and tell this woman to go about her business .

sp.speaker: SHREWISH VOICE
sp.p: It is my business !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: I 'll show you ! I was here first ; everything was going all right . Carter , are you going to come out here and do your duty like I said ? CARTERattempting sternness and failingYou shut that door ! I got to get this report in order before the meeting . I 'm not comin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: Then I wo n't be responsible for what happens ! She ai n't the only one . Mrs. Shomberg is out here messin ’ things up , too . If you wo n't do your duty there 'll be direct action took here !She goes out violently .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: That 's got to come up in meeting . It certainly has . These here wives ! For example , my wife 's an awful quiet woman , but you s'pose she 's goin ’ to stand it when she hears about all these others ? I 'd like to keep her at home .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: I just wonder —

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: What was you wondering , Miss Gorodna ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Well , if that 's something the meeting can settle ? CARTERdoggedlyWell , it 's got to vote on it .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: We did vote on Mrs. Simpson last meeting .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , we got to vote on her and all the rest of ‘ em this time .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: It did n't seem to settle Mrs. Simpson , did it ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , it had n't got so bad then . Now it 's got to be settled ! We got to git everything fixed up now .

div.stage: A frightful dispute is heard in numerous male voices ; some speaking Italian , some Yiddish , and some broken English . This grows louder as FRANKEL rushes in , throwing the door shut behind him and leaning against it , wiping his forehead .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Life ai n't worth livin ’ ! Life ai n't worth livin ’ !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Serves you right , Frankel !

div.stage: At the filter FRANKEL pours water from the glass upon a dirty handkerchief and passes the handkerchief over his forehead .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: I got to git some peace ! I got to collect myself .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: That shows you ai n't got no rights like you claimed . You can n't control your labour element . FRANKELbitterlyI 'll control ‘ em all right ! I 'll show ‘ em who 's their master !A man 's head with shaggy hair and ragged whiskers is thrust in at the factory door . This is POLENSKI .POLENSKIferociouslyAre you goin ’ to come out here like a man ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: You bet I 'm comin ’ out there , Polenski ! I 'll show you who 's the man here ! You Hunnyacks try to browbeat me !

div.stage: As he goes out , babbling fiercely , the howls of a Roman mob are heard greeting him .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: I do n't feel no sympathy with him .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: No ; I should think not !

div.stage: A more distant outbreak of the mob is heard , brief but fierce , and just a moment before it ceases MIFFLIN enters , beaming . He is dressed as usual , with his umbrella and the same old magazines and newspapers under his arm .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Everything is lovely ! How do you do , Miss Gorodna ! Carter , old fellow ! It 's a great morning , a great morning ! Mr. Gibson drove me down in his car . It 's wonderful to feel the inspiration it 's going to be for an ex-capitalist to see this place and its harmony . My phrase for it is “ harmonized industry . ” It will mark an epoch for him .

div.stage: GIBSON comes in . MIFFLIN greets him .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Ah , Mr. Gibson ! You 'll see a difference ! You 'll see a difference !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes , I do . Good morning , Miss Gorodna ! NORAjust barely looking roundGood morning , Mr. Gibson .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: I was just saying what an inspiration it 's going to be for you to see what we 're doing down here .Pats CARTER 'S shoulder .These noble fellows are teaching us intellectuals a lesson . I keep going among them ; what they 're doing here keeps flowing into me . You 'll get it , Mr. Gibson . You 'll get it , too !Beamingly he goes out into the factory .CARTERcordiallyTake a chair , Mr. Gibson . Make yourself right at home !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Thanks !He makes a grave tour of inspection of the place , his expression noncommittal ; goes about casually without making a point of it ; he writes his initials in the dust on a filing case . He turns and looks at NORA thoughtfully ; she has not seemed to notice him .Do you think I will , Miss Gorodna ? NORAnot looking upDo I think you will what ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: That I 'll get what Mifflin meant ? That it will be an inspiration to me to see this meeting ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: I do n't know what will be an inspiration to you .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I know one thing that is — a brave woman !The only sign she gives is that her head bends over her work just a little more .Carter , do you think this meeting is going to be an inspiration to me ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , Mr. Gibson , since the time you give up our rights to us , as Mr. Mifflin says , we 're an inspiration to the whole world . All the time ! Yes , sir ; and we would be , too , if we could jest git these dog-goned inequalities straightened out . We got this Frankel trouble on our hands , and them wives , and one thing and another , though they ai n't botherin ’ me so much as my own rights . But they 're goin ’ to git brought up in the meeting . You 'll see !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Is the safe usually kept open ? CARTERheartilyWhy , yes , sir ; open to each and all alike .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Oh , yes , of course ! Seems to be some business mail left over here .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Oh , yes . But you 'll find every one of ‘ em 's been opened ; we never miss opening a letter . You see they 's checks in some of ‘ em .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I see . Then everything is running right along , is it , Carter ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Oh , sure ! Right along , right along !

div.stage: The uproar breaks out again . FRANKEL bursts in , wiping his forehead as before . He hurries to the water filter for more water .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: By golly ! The bloodsuckers ! They want my life ! They do n't get it ! Hello , Mr. Gibson ! Well , I am pleased to see you ! Say , Mr. Gibson , lemme say something to you . Look here a minute .He draws GIBSON aside .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What is it , Frankel ? FRANKELhastily , in a low voiceMr. Gibson , keep it under your hat , but I got a pretty good interest in this factory right now . What date I 'm goin ’ to own it I wo n't say . But what I want to put up to you : How much would you ask me to manage it for me ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: I would n't be no piker ; when it comes to your salary you could pretty near set it yourself .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I 'm afraid I 've already had an offer that would keep me from accepting , Frankel .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: When the time comes I 'll git a manager somewhere ; no place like this can n't run itself ; I seen that much .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Even if I did n't have an offer , Frankel , I doubt if I 'd accept yours . You know I used to have some little trouble here .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: You got my sympathy now ! I got troubles myself here .Hastily drinks another glass of water .Well , where 's that meeting ? They 're late , ai n't they ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: If they are it 's your fault . Them wops of yours wo n't hardly let a body git by out yonder .

div.stage: SALVATORE and SHOMBERG come in from the factory , SALVATORE pausing in the doorway to shout in the direction of an audible disturbance in the distance .

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Oh , shut up ; you 'll git your pay !Following SALVATORE come SIMPSON and his wife and RILEY . They all speak rather casually but not uncordially to GIBSON . MIFFLIN is with them , his hand on SIMPSON 'S shoulder . The outbreak outside subsides in favour of a speech of extreme violence in a foreign language . Italian , Yiddish , or whatever it is , it seems most passionate , and by a good orator . It continues to be heard as the members of the committee take their seats at the big table . MIFFLIN beams and nods at GIBSON ; and takes his seat with the committee .SHOMBERGhotly , to MRS. SIMPSONHere , you ai n't a member of this committee ! Git her chair away from her there , Salvatore ! She 's got no right here !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: Oh , I have n't ?

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Already twice this morning I got hell from my own wife the way this woman treats her tryin ’ to chase her out the factory . You think you 're on this committee ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: taking a chair triumphantlyMy husband is . I was here last time , and I 'm goin ’ to keep on . CARTERreferring to the speech in the factoryMy goodness ! We can n't do no work .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Frankel , that 's your business to shut ‘ em up .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Talkin ’ ai n't doin ’ no harm . Let ‘ em talk .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Yes , I will !Goes to the door , and roarsCut that out ! I mean business !Shuts the door and returns angrily to his seat .CARTERrapping on the table with a rulerThe meeting will now come to order ! Minutes of the last meeting will now be read by the secretary . MIFFLINto GIBSON , beamingYou see ? NORArising , minute book in handThe meeting was called to order by Chairman Carter , Monday , the —

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Aw , say !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: I object !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: What 's the use readin ’ all that ? It 's only about what we done at the last meeting .

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: We know that ourselves , do n't we ?

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: What 'd be the use ? What 'd be the use ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: All we done was divide up the money .

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Cut it out , cut it out ! Let 's get to that !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: All right , then . I move —

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: shrillyYou can n't move . The chairman can n't move . If you want to move you better resign !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , then , somebody ought to move —

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: Cut out the moving . She do n't haf to read ‘ em , does she ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: All right , then . Do n't read ‘ em , Miss Gorodna .

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Well , git some kind of a move on .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: The next order of business —

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Oh , yes ! The next order of business —

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Is reports of committees . CARTERin a loud , confident voiceThe next order of business is reports of committees .Takes up some papers and goes on promptly .The first committee I will report on is my committee . I will state it is very difficult reading , because consisting of figures written by the bookkeeper , and pretty hard to make head or tail of , but —

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: Oh , here , say ! We got important things to come up here ! ‘ Fore we know how much we 're goin ’ to divide amongst us we got to settle at once for all and for the last time how it 's goin ’ to be divided and how much each family gets .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: You bet — family !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Yes , sir !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: You bet we 'll settle how it 's goin ’ to be divided !

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Why , even , of course ; just like it has been . Ai n't that the principle we struggled for all these years , comrades ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: Well , it 's not goin ’ to be divided even no longer . SALVATOREviolentlyYes , it is ! SIMPSON AND CARTERhotlyIt is not !

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: You bet your life it is !

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: I 'd sooner wring your neck , you sporty Dago !

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Now look here , comrade —

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Comrade ! Who you callin ’ comrade ? Do n't you comrade me !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: You dirty little Dago ! You got no wife to support ! Livin ’ a bachelor life of the worst kind , you think you 'll draw down as much as my man does ? SALVATOREfiercelySimpson , I do n't want to hit no lady , but if — SIMPSONroaringJust you try it ! MIFFLINrising in his place , still beaming , and tapping on the table with his fountain penGentlemen , gentlemen ! This is all healthy ! It 's a wholesome sign , and I like to see these little arguments . It shows you are thinking . But , of course , it has always been understood that in any such system of ideal brotherhood as we have here we , of course , cling to the equal distribution of all our labours . We — SALVATOREfiercelyWe ? How do you git in this ? Where do you git this we stuff ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Yes ; what you mean — we ?

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: You ai n't goin ’ to edge in here . Your kind 's done that other places . Some soft-handed guy that never done a day 's work in his life but write and make speeches , works in and gits workingmen to elect him at the top and then runs ‘ em just the same as any capitalist . MIFFLINmildly protestingOh , but you must n't — SALVATOREsullenlyThat 's all right ; I read the news from Russia ! MIFFLINfirmly beamingBut I was upholding your contention for an equal distribution . SALVATOREmuch surprised and mollifiedOh , that 's all right then ; I did n't git you !

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Right comrade ! I 'm always for the under dog .

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Call him an under dog ! He 's a loafer and do n't know a trade !

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: He was gettin ’ three and a half a day , and now he draws what I do !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: attacking RILEY fiercelyYes , and you 're gettin ’ as much as my husband is , and your wife left you seven years ago and you livin ’ on the fat of the land ; Steinwitz 's pool parlour every night till all hours ! SHOMBERGattacking herYes , and you and your husband ai n't got no children ; we got four . I 'd like to know what right you got to draw down what we do — you with your limousine !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: What business you got to talk , Shomberg ? When here 's me with my seven and the three of my married daughter — eleven in all , I got on my shoulders . Do you think you 're goin ’ to draw down what I 'd ought to ? ALLshouting“ Here ! We got rights , ai n't we ? ” “ Where 's the justice of it ? ” “ I stand by my rights . ” “ Nobody 's goin ’ to git ‘ em away from me . ” “ I bet I git my share . ” “ Oh , dry up ! ” “ You make me laugh ! ” And so on . RILEYstanding up and pounding the table , roaring till they are forced to listenYou ai n't any of you got the rights of it ! The rights of it is — Who does the most work gets the most money . Look at me on that truck ! CARTERpounding on the table with a rulerYou set down , Riley ! The rights of it ai n't who does the most work ; but I 'm willin ’ to leave it to who does the hardest work .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: No , sir ! It 's who does the best work .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: There ai n't only three men in my department out there that ai n't soldiering on their job . I do twice as much skilled work as any man at this table , and I do it better .Shouts of “ Yes , you do ! ” “ Rats ! ” “ Shut up ! ”I 'll leave it to Mr. Gibson ; he knows good work if he do n't know nothing else .Shouts of “ Leave it to nothing ! ” “ How 'd he get in this ? ” “ You 're crazy ! ”CARTERbawlingGet back to business ! We 're running a meeting here !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: For goodness ’ sake , we ai n't getting nowhere !

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: No , and you ai n't never goin ’ to git nowhere long as you try to work big business and privilege on me ! We got to keep it like Mr. Mifflin says ; it 's a sacred brotherhood , everything divided equal . Let 's get to business and count that money .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Well , for goodness ’ sake , let 's get some system into this meeting !

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: How you goin ’ to get any system into it before you settle what 's going to be done about Frankel 's twenty-four shares ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Twenty-four ? He 's got twenty-six ; he got two more yesterday !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: He 's got thirty-five ; he got nine more this morning ! FRANKELhotlyYou bet I got thirty-five !

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: What ! Thirty-five shares !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Well , ai n't I got thirty-five men workin ’ out there ?

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: How in thunder we goin ’ to settle about him holdin ’ all them shares ?

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Are we goin ’ to let him take all that money ? Thirty-five — FRANKELleaping up , electrifiedHow d'you expect I 'm goin ’ to pay my men if I do n't get it ? Are you goin ’ to let me take them thirty-five shares ’ profits ? No , I guess you ai n't ! You ai n't got no say about it ! The money 's mine right now ! I get it !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: I object ! RILEYpounding the tableLook at the ornery little devil ! He took advantage of the poor workingmen 's trustfulness , got ‘ em in debt to him , then went and begun buying over their shares , so they had to leave the shop because he would n't hire ‘ em to do their own work , but went and hired cheaper men . Listen to the trouble they make among us !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: It 's an undesirable element .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: He had no right to buy them workmen out in the first place .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: And on top of that we can n't git no work turned out because the fourteen skilled men he 's got in there have gone and started striking just like the unskilled and they tie up everything .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: I claim he had n't no right to buy them shares .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: I did n't ? ALLexcept SHOMBERGNo , you did n't ! FRANKELhotly at RILEYYou look here . S'pose you needed money bad ? Ai n't you got a right to sell your share ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Sure I have !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: What you talkin ’ about , then ? Ai n't I got a right to buy anything you got a right to sell ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: No , you ai n't , because I object to the whole system .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: You do !Points to SHOMBERG .Look there ! Ask him what he says . He 's got four .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: I do n't care who 's got what ! All I say is I object to the system , and this factory 'll git burned up if them wop workmen stay here jest because he holds them shares !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: You 're right about that , Riley !

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Why , you can n't hear yourself think out in the shops when you might be havin ’ a quiet talk with a friend .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: When them wops gits to talkin ’ strike it sounds more like a revolution to me !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Why , they 're all inflamed up . They know what 's what , all right .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: What do they know ?

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: They know you 're drawing down on them shares about five or six times the wages you pay ‘ em . What I claim is that extra money he makes ought to be divided amongst us .

div.stage: Emphatic approval from CARTER , SIMPSON , and RILEY . “ Yes sir ! You bet ! That 's what ! ”

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Just try it once !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Them men ai n't workin ’ for you , they 're workin ’ for us . Ai n't we the original owners ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Y-a-a-a-h ! RILEYpounding the tableThat 's the stuff ! We 're the original owners ! Any money made on them wops ’ wages is ours . We 'll tend to business with them !

div.stage: The noise outside has increased deafeningly ; there is a loud hammering on the door , which is now flung open , and POLENSKI in patched overalls , a wrench in his hand , enters fiercely , slamming the door behind him . He begins an oration at the door .

sp.speaker: POLENSKI
sp.p: Do n't we git a hearing ? We got to take direct action in this rotten factory before we even get a word in .Shouts from the committee : “ Get out of here , you wop ! ” “ You ai n't got no business here ! ” “ This a committee meeting ! ”Committee meeting , my nose !Shakes his fist at FRANKEL .Do you know what you 're up against ? You 're up against the arm of labour ! You monkey with labour a little more the way you have , and you 'll be glad if it 's only a little nitroglycerin that gits you . Hired us for two and a half , did you ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: My goodness , I rose you to three this morning !

sp.speaker: POLENSKI
sp.p: Yes ; rose us to three ! What do we care you rose us to four , to five , to six . Look what the rest you loafers here at this table is gittin ’ !

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Here , do n't you bring us in this ! POLENSKIhalf screamingI wo n't ? Every one of you is in his class .Points at FRANKEL .You sit up here and call yourself a committee , dividin ’ up the money and runnin ’ this factory that belongs just as much to us men he hired as it does to you ! It belongs to us more — because we 're the real workin'men !Beats his chest .My God ! Do n't the toilers ’ wrongs never git avenged ? Are we always goin ’ to be wage slaves ? We demand simple justice . We been workin ’ here two dollars and a half a day , now we want the wage scale abolished and double profits for each of us for every day we worked here before we found out what was goin ’ on , with you sittin ’ up here like kings in your robes , tellin ’ the poor man he should have only two dollars and a half a day — sittin ’ up here in your pomp with your feet on the neck of labour !To CARTERYou , in your fine broadcloth , ridin ’ up and down the avenues in limousines with never a thought for the toiler ! Do n't think for a minute we deal with this little vampire here . You 're all in the same boat , and the toiling masses will hold every single one of you just as responsible as it does him , you — you capitalists !

div.stage: Instantly upon this the door is opened enough to admit the heads of two wops very similar to POLENSKI .

sp.speaker: FIRST WOP
sp.p: Parasites !

sp.speaker: SECOND WOP
sp.p: Bloodsuckers !

sp.speaker: POLENSKI
sp.p: Capitalists , parasites , bloodsuckers , bourgeoisie ! Do you think we expect any justice out of you ? Do you think I come in this room ever dreaming you 'd grant our demands ? No ! We knew you ! And if we do assert our rights , what do you do ? You set your hellhounds of police on us ! Have n't we been agitatin ’ for our rights among you for days ? We 've got our answer from you , but you look out for ours , because as sure as there is a hell waitin ’ for all parasites , we 'll send you there , and your factory , too !Looks up at the clock .My God , is that clock right ?He runs out at top speed .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: They do n't seem to know their place !

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Them fellers think they own the earth .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Next , they 'll be thinkin ’ they own our factory ! CARTERsolemnlyWell , sir , I wonder what this country is coming to !Here there is a muffled explosion in the sample piano , which rocks with the jar , at the same time emitting a few curls of smoke . General exclamations of horror and fright as all of the committee break for shelter .SHOMBERGhis voice rising over the othersSend for the police ! SALVATOREshoutingWait ! We ai n't divided up the money !

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: It 's over ; it has n't done any harm ! FRANKELon his hands and knees under the tableIt was in that piano .NORA goes across to the piano .Look out , he 's probably got another one in there .MIFFLIN helps NORA to take off the front of the piano , which is still mildly smoking ; a wreckage of wires is seen .MIFFLINsmilingIt must have been an accident !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL AND MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: coming out from under the tableAccident !

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: Of course it 's unfortunate , because it might be misconstrued .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Yes , it might . MIFFLINconfidentlyLet me go talk to these new comrades !

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Comrades ? Frankel 's wops ? Ha , ha !

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Aw , them ai n't comrades ; them 's just Frankel 's hired workers .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: They are comrades in the best sense of the word . I am in touch with all the groups . A moment 's reasoning from one they know to be sympathetic —

div.stage: He goes out into the factory .

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Hey , let 's get that stuff divided up . I got an engagement .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Yes ; let 's hurry . You can n't tell what they got planted round here . CARTERrappingThe meeting will please come to —

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Here , cut that out ! We ai n't got no time to —

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: No . Come to business ; come to business !

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: The only way , comrades , to know how much we have gained since the last division is to read the bookkeeper 's report .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Well , for heaven 's sakes , go on — read it !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , I did want to a long while ago , when we first set down and begun the meeting . I says then , I report on my committee and —

sp.speaker: VARIOUS MEMBERS
sp.p: Oh , for heaven 's sake ! Go ahead ! Cut it out ! CARTERpicking up the sheetsOn the first page is says Soomary .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: What 's that mean ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: Oh , my goodness !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Git to the figures !

lg.l: : Well , here , on one side it says gross receipts —

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: What ? SIMPSONshoutingRead it !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Gross receipts $ 2 , 162. 43 . On the other side it says : “ Cash paid out $ 19 , 461. 53 . ”All are puzzled .It did n't sound right to me , even the first time I read it . Looks like he 's got the wrong words , crossed over .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Why , gross receipts last month was over twenty-four thousand dollars !

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Yes , and that was a fall off from the month before . CARTERrubbing his headWell , I do n't pretend to understand it , but he told me all them was mostly payments on old sales anyhow .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Read it again , read it again !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Yes , let 's see if we can n't get what the sense of it is .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: It says “ Gross receipts , $ 2 , 162. 43 ” — that 's over here . “ Cash paid out , $ 19 , 461. 53 . ”

div.stage: All seem dazed .

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: What else you got there ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: As near as it seems to me , just a lot of items .

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: Well , we must have a lot of money in the bank ; what 's the matter we draw that out and divide it ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Wait a minute ! What 's there besides them items ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: He 's got a note . “ Note , ” he says ; here it is : He says : “ Bank notified us this morning we 're overdrawn $ 59. 01 . ”

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Overdrawn ?

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Then we got to deposit some to our account . Who 's got charge of the checks that comes in ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: The bookkeeper has charge , but there are n't any checks .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: No , they ai n't been any checks comin ’ in for some days ; a week or so , or two weeks , you might say . We 've looked everywhere for ‘ em — FRANKELaghastYou looked all through them letters ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: They ai n't none left in ‘ em that was n't took out a good while ago .

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: You ai n't looked through the safe , have you ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: They ai n't a one in it ; it 's got me all puzzled up , I tell you . I was jest waitin ’ for the meeting to settle it .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: But heaven 's sakes ! There must be checks comin ’ in from new sales !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: It says here sales has fallen off . So fur this month they was only three instruments sold .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: But , my gosh , this is the end of the month !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: They was two sold in Council Bluffs and one in Detroit .

div.stage: General agitation and excitement .

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: trembling with rage and fearYou mean to stand there and tell me we ai n't goin ’ to git any money to-day , and my flat rent to pay to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Do n't talk about your flat rent to me , lady ! There 's others of us got a few things to pay .

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: But , my golly , when do we git paid ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: I can n't make out from what he 's got here . SALVATORErapping fiercely on the tableHey ! I got to have my money !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , I got to have mine , do n't I ?

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Go on . See what else it says .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , here he 's got this . Here it says : “ Bills payable , $ 17 , 162. 48 . ” FRANKELleaping upBills payable ! My God , no money in bank , and we 're $ 17 , 162. 48 in debt !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: shriekingWho owes it ?

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: We do !

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Who 's goin ’ to pay it ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: Who run us into debt that way ?

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: That 's the man we 're after !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Who 's the man responsible for us bein ’ $ 17 , 162. 48 bankrupt ? RILEYhammering the tableWho run us into debt over seventeen thousand dollars ?

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Well , give him a chance to answer .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: What do I know about it ? That 's what the report says . That 's all I know .

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Well , somebody 's got us into debt . And who is it ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: It 's all of us ! Have n't we all done this thing together ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Well , who 's got to pay it ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: We 've all got to !

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG , SALVATORE , FRANKEL , AND MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: You expect to git blood out of a stone ? What do you take us for ? You 're crazy ! You helped get us into this !SHOMBERG and SALVATORE begin shouting at each other .

lg.l: : You pay me back that twenty-five dollars you got from me

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: How I 'm goin ’ to pay you twenty-five dollars when I 'm seventeen thousand dollars in debt ?

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: I 'll have that money !

div.stage: He takes a paper weight from desk .

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: You throw that at me , I 'll give you a little sticker where you wo n't like it !

div.stage: Puts his hand in the breast of his coat . Murder appears imminent . Sudden and general dispersal from the neighbourhood of the combatants , which brings NORA to GIBSON , unconsciously seeking his protection .

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Aw , I did n't mean anything serious like that .Puts down the paper weight .But I 'll get the money .

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: You 'll need it — to pay your share what we owe !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: I 'd like to see ‘ em get one cent out of me !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: It ai n't just us here of course ; they 's a hundred and seventy men outside the debt belongs to as well as us . The whole factory 's got to pay it .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Great gosh ! Do you think we can go out there , when they 're expectin ’ a month 's pay , and tell ‘ em they 're gettin ’ only a seventeen-thousand-dollar debt ?

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: And me , me , me ! Look at me ! Do you think I can go out and tell them thirty-five bloodhounds I ai n't got no money to even pay their wages ? RILEYvehementlyWhat 's more , you owe thirty-five shares of that debt , Frankel ! ALLwith vindictive satisfactionThat 's it ! Sure he does ! He owes thirty-five shares of the debt ! That 's right !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: You owe thirty-five shares of the seventeen-thousand debt .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: My heavens ! Ai n't the meetin ’ just settled it I did n't have no right to them shares and it was all to be divided even ?

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: What we got to do , we got to go out there and tell ‘ em they owe this money .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: I can n't tell mine !

sp.speaker: SALVATORE
sp.p: I know one game little fellow that ai n't goin ’ to pay nobody nothin ’ . Excuse me , gents ; they 'll have to find me !

div.stage: He goes out hastily by the door that leads to the street .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , somebody 's got to go out there and tell ‘ em .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Well , I wo n't !

sp.speaker: MRS. SIMPSON
sp.p: It 's the chairman 's place .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: We all got to go !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Not me !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: Yes , you will !Takes him by the shoulders .RILEYtaking him from SIMPSONPut him first !They begin to jostle toward the factory door .FRANKELas they push him he waves a despairing hand at GIBSONMr. Gibson , that was a fine trick you played on us ! THE COMMITTEEshoutingYou go on there ! Come on ! We got to take our medicine !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: Lemme alone ! Take your hands off me !

div.stage: They jostle out , leaving NORA and GIBSON alone together . NORA has gone to the large table , sitting beside it , with her head far down between her hands . As the noise dies away MIFFLIN comes in from the factory .

sp.speaker: MIFFLIN
sp.p: What wonderful spirits ! Just great , rough boys !Smiles as he gets his hat , magazines , newspaper , and umbrella .Everything is working out . Some little inevitable friction here , some little setback there . But it all works , it all works to the one great end . I 'm sorry I was n't present for the end of the meeting to hear what success there was this month , but that 's a detail . The dream has come true . It 's here , and we 're living it !At the door .I 'll send you a copy of my next article , Mr. Gibson .Modestly laughs .They tell me the series is making a little sensation in its way . Good morning !

div.stage: He goes out jauntily . GIBSON has never moved from his chair ; he turns his head , still not rising , and looks fixedly at NORA . She slowly lifts her head , meets his eye ; her head sinks again . He rises and slowly walks over to her , looking down at her . Then , bending still lower , she begins to cry .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , Nora , what was the matter with it ? NORAnot looking upI do n't know . What was ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You needed a manager to do what I had been doing .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Could n't we have learned ? Could n't one of us ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: One of you did — Hill .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: But he left !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Why did Hill leave ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Other people offered him more money .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes ; he was the one man that all the rest of you depended on . He was worth more .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: But were you worth all that you took ? You took all that the business made .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes ; and last year it was fifty thousand .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Were you actually worth that much to it ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Other men in the business think so .Shows her a letter .Here 's an offer from the Coles-Hibbard people , out in Cleveland , of that much salary to do for them what I did here .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: It is n't right ; you pay labour only what you have to pay .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: The Coles-Hibbard people offer to pay me what they 'd have to , and they 're pretty hard-headed men . The whole world pays only what it has to .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: It is n't right ! It is n't right !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Last winter I saw you in a three-dollar seat listening to Caruso . Have you ever given that much to the organ grinder who comes under these windows ?

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Will it always be so ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I do n't know . But it 's so now .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: But will the plan always fail ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I think it will until human beings are as near alike as the ants and bees are . Your system is in full effect with them , but we — we strive ; even in this fellowship here of yours the striving began to show . NORAlooking up at him appealinglyBut are these inequalities right ? GIBSONgently , rather sadlyI do n't know . I only know what is .

sp.speaker: NORA
sp.p: Well — I 'm whipped .Smiles ruefully , away from him ; then she turns again to him .Are you going to accept that offer ?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What do you say ?

div.stage: Her head droops again . Angry voices are heard , growing louder as they approach . The door is thrown open , and the members of the committee , noisily talking , appear in the doorway .

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: It was a bum deal all through !

sp.speaker: SHOMBERG
sp.p: Shovin ’ his run-down factory off onto us ! RILEYfiercelyYou never give us no deed to this plant , Mr. Gibson !

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: They ai n't a court in the land 'll hold us to it !

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: No , sir ; and we 've voted this is your factory , Mr. Gibson ! We ai n't responsible !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: It is my factory and I 'm going to run it ! Any man of you not back at work in ten minutes on the old scale of wages will be fired !

div.stage: The members whoop with joy . FRANKEL and CARTER both try to shake hands with GIBSON at once .

sp.speaker: CARTER
sp.p: Well , that 's a relief to me . Thank you , Mr. Gibson !

sp.speaker: FRANKEL
sp.p: That takes a heap off my mind !

sp.speaker: RILEY
sp.p: God bless you , sir !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Never mind that ! You go back to work .

div.stage: Whooping , the committee , in great spirits and with the greatest friendliness to one another , depart rapidly . Closing the door , GIBSON turns briskly to NORA , and speaks in a businesslike way .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Nora , will you marry me ? NORAmeeklyYes — I will .

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Will you marry me to-day ? NORAwith a little more spiritYes , I will !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Will you go with me and marry me right now ? NORAmore loudly and promptlyYes , I will !

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well , then —

div.stage: He gets his hat and coat , then thinks of something he wants from his desk and goes over to get it . Meantime NORA , not moving so rapidly as GIBSON , but more thoughtfully , goes up to the wall where hang her jacket and hat , takes off her apron , puts on the jacket and hat and goes to the door that leads to the street , where she stands waiting . There is a knock on the factory door , which opens without waiting , and SIMPSON comes in .

sp.speaker: SIMPSON
sp.p: I do n't want to detain you if you 're goin ’ out , Mr. Gibson , but there 's something 's got to be settled . And the men in my department say it 's got to be settled right now . That wage scale says we get time and a half for overtime , and the men in the finishing department , they ai n't gettin ’ no time and a half on piecework and we never understood that agreement you claim we signed with you anyhow . So what we says , if we do n't get double time instead of time and a half for overtime — why , Mr. Gibson , it looks like them men could n't hardly be held back . Now what we demand is —

div.stage: He is still talking as the final curtain descends upon these three : GIBSON seated at his desk , looking fixedly at SIMPSON , NORA waiting thoughtfully by the door that leads to the street .
CURTAIN
